Here are the products we recommend...   The best hydrating night cream Clinique Moisture Surge Overnight Mask, £30   For those that need a extra boost of moisturise, it's worth switching your night cream for a mask throughout winter or for two-to-three nights a week. Clinique Moisture Surge Overnight Mask is packed full of nourishing ingredients and has the most creamy soft texture. Apply from the decolletage upwards and pat on an extra layer where required. The cream promises to target all five signs of ageing and has independent clinical studies to prove that within 28 days you could see 52 percent improvement in your lines and wrinkles. Admittedly these kind of results do come with a hefty price tag, but if you're serious about ageing, this is worth the investment.    Buy now The best night cream for pigmentation Dr Dennis Gross Ferulic and Retinol Wrinkle Recovery Overnight Serum, £77 While this isn't technically a 'night cream', this potent serum is one of the best solutions to pigmentation that I've come across. The blend of retinol and ferulic acid helps to even out skin tone and reduce the appearance of dark spots. Don't expect overnight miracles though, you do have to persevere for at least 12 weeks to see improvement.  Buy now How retinoids work in your skincare products 02:14 The best night cream for sensitive skin  La Roche Posay Toleriane Ultra Overnight Care, £13.12 La Roche Posay's Toleriane range has a reputation for being one of the very best skincare ranges for sensitive skin and four of the products are approved by the British Allergy Foundation. There have been 60 venomous snake bites reported in Mecklenburg County between March 1 and Oct. 15, according to the data. That comes to about two bites per week, or one every 3.8 days. The county is ranked No. 2 in the state for venomous snake bites, among 100 counties. So which county is No. 1? Wake County, home of the state capital, with 82 venomous venomous bites since March 1, according to the data.

Chinese Professor Sends Warning to KJU: Another Missile Test Means War
BY KIM SMITH 
OCTOBER 23, 2017 AT 3:47PM
A Chinese professor who reportedly has close ties to the government in Beijing said the country would be willing to go to war with North Korea if dictator Kim Jong Un doesn’t stop its dangerous missile testing.
Chong Sho-Hu, a professor of International Relations at Renmin University, said Kim Jong-Un was “seeking death” with continued threats of nuclear war, according to a report from the U.K. Express.
Speaking to the BBC Radio 4, the professor warned that one more missile test from North Korea could be the move “to push the country off the cliff.”
The professor said that it could be time for military intervention with the rogue nation.
Despite the relationship between the two countries, Chong warned that president Xi Jinping was reportedly “fed up” with Kim’s unstable behavior, adding that Xi is angry with North Korea and wants to punish them.
“There are no permanent friends and no permanent enemies,” Chong said, pointing out that China once had a special relationship with the Soviet Union and Vietnam but also went to war with them.
“The relationship between China and North Korea is worse than both of those,” he added.
“North Korea is in an awkward situation. No country has ever encountered such tough sanctions before. If they do nothing, they will starve to death. If they do another ICBM test, they will seek to die.”
He continued, “North Korea is standing on the edge of a deep cliff, one light blow could push this country of the cliff.”

context_meta.author: Yahoo News
context_meta.title: From shark attacks to major storms, 2 mariners share their 5 months lost at sea
context_meta.summary: Two women mariners adrift in the Pacific Ocean for five months endured two days of shark attacks on their sailboat and major storms before being rescued by a U.S. Navy warship nearly 5,000 miles from their intended destination of Tahiti. On May 3, Appel, an experienced sailor, and Fuiva, a sailing novice, set sail from Honolulu aboard the 50-foot "Sea Nymph" bound for Tahiti, 2,600 miles to the south. Soon after that, they endured an intense storm with almost hurricane winds and 25-foot waves that buffeted their sailboat for two days.

context_meta.title: Afraid of venomous snakes? Mecklenburg has had 60 bites reported since March 1.
context_meta.summary: Wondering why the Charlotte area has recently had a lot of copperhead bites, with four reports over a two-week span? Well, turns out Mecklenburg County is one of the places in the state where you're most likely to be bitten by a venomous snake, based on data from the Carolinas Poison Center. There have been 60 venomous snake bites reported in Mecklenburg County between March 1 and Oct. 15, according to the data. That comes to about two bites per week, or one every 3.8 days. The county is ranked No. 2 in the state for venomous snake bites, among 100 counties. So which county is No. 1? Wake County, home of the state capital, with 82 venomous venomous bites since March 1, according to the data.

context_meta.author: Yahoo News
context_meta.title: North Korea steps up security around monuments to Kim family as anger grows over poor living standards
context_meta.summary: North Korea has stepped up security around statues and other larger-than-life monuments to the ruling Kim family, apparently out of concern that they might be vandalised by a disgruntled - and increasingly hungry - citizenry. Citing its sources within North Korea, the Seoul-based Daily NK news web site said police "have been mobilised for night patrols" around statues dedicated to the three generations of the Kim family that have ruled the nation since 1945, while additional care is being taken across the country to protect wall murals and oil paintings in public places that extol their heroic achievements. Guards are traditionally assigned to statues and other landmarks designed to unite the North Korean people behind their leadership on national holidays and anniversaries linked to the Kim family, but that protection is being stepped up. "Agencies have constantly been saying 'Use lights to illuminate statues and paintings of the three generals of the Mount Paekyu bloodline [the Kim dynasty] and thoroughly care for them to ensure that hostile elements cannot damage them'," a source in Pyongyang told the dissident publication. "There have been reports of incidents targeting these statues and monuments to the Kim family, particularly in the more remote areas of the country," said Toshimitsu Shigemura, a professor at Tokyo's Waseda University and an authority on North Korea's ruling family. Statues of former leaders Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il Credit: REUTERS  "And, in comparison with the past, these incidents are becoming more frequent," he told The Telegraph. "Younger generations of North Koreans have little respect for Kim Jong-un and we are beginning to see that come to the surface," he said. People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry "And local authorities have no choice but to increase security around these monuments because it could cost them their jobs - or worse - if such protests begin to spread."  Discontent with the regime may well increase in the coming months, after North Korea suffered a severe drought at the beginning of its crop growing season, which will inevitably have an impact on the harvest. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation has already warned of "a sharp increase of food insecurity levels" and other agencies have warned of widespread hunger among the population. Pyongyang has also requested assistance from the UN to feed its people, a step it has not had to take for several years. "Despite all his promises, Kim Jong-un has had no significant successes and the people know it," Professor Shigemura said. "People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry."

context_meta.author: Yahoo News
context_meta.title: North Korea steps up security around monuments to Kim family as anger grows over poor living standards
context_meta.summary: North Korea has stepped up security around statues and other larger-than-life monuments to the ruling Kim family, apparently out of concern that they might be vandalised by a disgruntled - and increasingly hungry - citizenry. Citing its sources within North Korea, the Seoul-based Daily NK news web site said police "have been mobilised for night patrols" around statues dedicated to the three generations of the Kim family that have ruled the nation since 1945, while additional care is being taken across the country to protect wall murals and oil paintings in public places that extol their heroic achievements. Guards are traditionally assigned to statues and other landmarks designed to unite the North Korean people behind their leadership on national holidays and anniversaries linked to the Kim family, but that protection is being stepped up. "Agencies have constantly been saying 'Use lights to illuminate statues and paintings of the three generals of the Mount Paekyu bloodline [the Kim dynasty] and thoroughly care for them to ensure that hostile elements cannot damage them'," a source in Pyongyang told the dissident publication. "There have been reports of incidents targeting these statues and monuments to the Kim family, particularly in the more remote areas of the country," said Toshimitsu Shigemura, a professor at Tokyo's Waseda University and an authority on North Korea's ruling family. Statues of former leaders Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il Credit: REUTERS  "And, in comparison with the past, these incidents are becoming more frequent," he told The Telegraph. "Younger generations of North Koreans have little respect for Kim Jong-un and we are beginning to see that come to the surface," he said. People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry "And local authorities have no choice but to increase security around these monuments because it could cost them their jobs - or worse - if such protests begin to spread."  Discontent with the regime may well increase in the coming months, after North Korea suffered a severe drought at the beginning of its crop growing season, which will inevitably have an impact on the harvest. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation has already warned of "a sharp increase of food insecurity levels" and other agencies have warned of widespread hunger among the population. Pyongyang has also requested assistance from the UN to feed its people, a step it has not had to take for several years. "Despite all his promises, Kim Jong-un has had no significant successes and the people know it," Professor Shigemura said. "People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry."

context_meta.title: North Korea steps up security around monuments to Kim family as anger grows over poor living standards
context_meta.summary: North Korea has stepped up security around statues and other larger-than-life monuments to the ruling Kim family, apparently out of concern that they might be vandalised by a disgruntled - and increasingly hungry - citizenry. Citing its sources within North Korea, the Seoul-based Daily NK news web site said police "have been mobilised for night patrols" around statues dedicated to the three generations of the Kim family that have ruled the nation since 1945, while additional care is being taken across the country to protect wall murals and oil paintings in public places that extol their heroic achievements. Guards are traditionally assigned to statues and other landmarks designed to unite the North Korean people behind their leadership on national holidays and anniversaries linked to the Kim family, but that protection is being stepped up. "Agencies have constantly been saying 'Use lights to illuminate statues and paintings of the three generals of the Mount Paekyu bloodline [the Kim dynasty] and thoroughly care for them to ensure that hostile elements cannot damage them'," a source in Pyongyang told the dissident publication. "There have been reports of incidents targeting these statues and monuments to the Kim family, particularly in the more remote areas of the country," said Toshimitsu Shigemura, a professor at Tokyo's Waseda University and an authority on North Korea's ruling family. Statues of former leaders Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il Credit: REUTERS  "And, in comparison with the past, these incidents are becoming more frequent," he told The Telegraph. "Younger generations of North Koreans have little respect for Kim Jong-un and we are beginning to see that come to the surface," he said. People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry "And local authorities have no choice but to increase security around these monuments because it could cost them their jobs - or worse - if such protests begin to spread."  Discontent with the regime may well increase in the coming months, after North Korea suffered a severe drought at the beginning of its crop growing season, which will inevitably have an impact on the harvest. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation has already warned of "a sharp increase of food insecurity levels" and other agencies have warned of widespread hunger among the population. Pyongyang has also requested assistance from the UN to feed its people, a step it has not had to take for several years. "Despite all his promises, Kim Jong-un has had no significant successes and the people know it," Professor Shigemura said. "People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry."

I had the worst diarrhea of my life a few months ago after eating at Applebee's. I got sick while I was in the mall and it hit very suddenly. The closest toilet was in Sears so I waddled as fast as I could to get to the bathroom before a river of brown erupted from my butt. Alas I discovered that the only bathroom in Sears was on the second floor, so after futilely searching I had to make for the escalator. I could feel the butt-volcano about to erupt, I was frantic. I thought OK, almost there, I can make it, and then I learned that the bathroom was all the way on the far side of the store from the escalator! This was bad, really bad. I had my sphincter clenched as tight as I could but I knew I had only seconds left and the bathroom was about half a minute away. If I sprinted I could make it, but if I sprinted I wouldn't be able to properly clench my sphincter. I was stuck. I did the best I could, and I even made it to the bathroom, but before I could get to the stall Mt. Buttuvius erupted in my pants. And it just kept coming. I waddled to the stall with a brown geyser shooting from my bum, got my pants down, and my butt kept spraying like the world's most foul fire hose. It got all over the seat, the toilet, the walls, the floor, there was even some on the ceiling. The CEILING! I had to pant and breathe deeply but the smell was so bad I almost vomited. So there I was, in Sears, my pants a wet, slimy, nasty brown. The only good thing was that there wasn't anybody in there, and all through my struggle, nobody else came in. I did what I had to do. I used two entire rolls of toilet paper to try to clean up, and I had to try to flush my underwear into the toilet. As you can imagine, this didn't work, so the toilet overflowed and spilled fecal juice all over the bathroom. I used a third roll of toilet paper to try to clean up before giving up. I tied my jacket around my waist to hide the brown stain on the back of my pants and made a hasty yet stealthy retreat, leaving a bathroom ruined with the worst diarrhea in human history in my wake. There were no written records from North America, but Japan has been keeping written records of Tsunamis for at least 1200 years.  In January of 1700 there was a Tsunami in Japan with no associated earthquake found.  The USGS scientists were able to place the quake on the Cascadian Subduction Zone within hours.

context_meta.title: North Korea steps up security around monuments to Kim family as anger grows over poor living standards
context_meta.summary: North Korea has stepped up security around statues and other larger-than-life monuments to the ruling Kim family, apparently out of concern that they might be vandalised by a disgruntled - and increasingly hungry - citizenry. Citing its sources within North Korea, the Seoul-based Daily NK news web site said police "have been mobilised for night patrols" around statues dedicated to the three generations of the Kim family that have ruled the nation since 1945, while additional care is being taken across the country to protect wall murals and oil paintings in public places that extol their heroic achievements. Guards are traditionally assigned to statues and other landmarks designed to unite the North Korean people behind their leadership on national holidays and anniversaries linked to the Kim family, but that protection is being stepped up. "Agencies have constantly been saying 'Use lights to illuminate statues and paintings of the three generals of the Mount Paekyu bloodline [the Kim dynasty] and thoroughly care for them to ensure that hostile elements cannot damage them'," a source in Pyongyang told the dissident publication. "There have been reports of incidents targeting these statues and monuments to the Kim family, particularly in the more remote areas of the country," said Toshimitsu Shigemura, a professor at Tokyo's Waseda University and an authority on North Korea's ruling family. Statues of former leaders Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il Credit: REUTERS  "And, in comparison with the past, these incidents are becoming more frequent," he told The Telegraph. "Younger generations of North Koreans have little respect for Kim Jong-un and we are beginning to see that come to the surface," he said. People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry "And local authorities have no choice but to increase security around these monuments because it could cost them their jobs - or worse - if such protests begin to spread."  Discontent with the regime may well increase in the coming months, after North Korea suffered a severe drought at the beginning of its crop growing season, which will inevitably have an impact on the harvest. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation has already warned of "a sharp increase of food insecurity levels" and other agencies have warned of widespread hunger among the population. Pyongyang has also requested assistance from the UN to feed its people, a step it has not had to take for several years. "Despite all his promises, Kim Jong-un has had no significant successes and the people know it," Professor Shigemura said. "People want food and better living standards; they do not care about nuclear weapons and missiles and they are asking why so much is being spent on them when they are hungry."
